fields.description: Corrupt images are being sent from walrus to the NC's due to incorrect error handling.
fields.summary: Error handling to prevent corrupt images being sent from walrus to node controller.

comments.body:
To Reproduce:
Topology: POC with 5 NC's
{code}
1) Use attached script on walrus host to clear the walrus image cache
   i.e. euca-modify-property -f euca=./flush_image_cache.groovy 
2) Clear instance cache on all NC's 
   a) rm -rf /var/lib/eucalyptus/instances/cache/*
   b) Restart NC's
3) Launch n instances of xGB where n * x is larger than free memory
4) Some or all instances will fail to start.
{code}

 I used 18 5GB images.

Error that ends up in NC instance cache file:
{code}

[~kedwards] The fix for this is very trivial, it is just a matter of catching and logging the error. We are already doing similar logging where the row may have been updated or deleted.I can have this fix ready for review tomorrow. With the fix all instances will start and an error will be logged.

Code Review Request : EUCA-9594 Error handling to prevent corrupt images being sent from walrus to node controller.

branch : dev/mmunn1/EUCA-9594

diff :  git show --color 3d9740beb1cd6233a2f9c0fd07baa283abc361ab

Summary: Corrupt images are being sent from walrus to the NC's due to incorrect error handling. 
         OptimisticLockException was not being handled and was propagated back to the NC image cache
         as text and causing the instance to fail at startup.

Solution: Handle and log the OptimisticLockException which allows the transaction to be retried and the image 
          to be cached on the NC properly. 

Unit test : in comments

Thx Mike
[~mmunn1], fantastic!  [~neil], [~swathi], [~zhill] could one of you review (its in Walrus).  I'd like this to go into 3.4.3 as its a trivial fix.
Verified this use case multiple times without any issues. Used a machine with 8G of RAM and 21 instances of a 2G image going to 5 different NCs.
